instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: m1 MacBook Pro, with small issue,  everything works except touchbar, the Touch Bar doesn’t power on after start up, but it  will work if lid is closed and then opened there is no liquid damage and the Touchbar connectors look perfect,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Possibly AMR sensor issue.
The one connected to JR900 is first suspect.
Check UR200 signals behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: i a another 2020 m1 13" also no touch bar, this one had liquid damage, hard replace the connector JT700 pins 22,14,21 were in rough shape, had to run wire for pin 14, the others had enough pad to rebuild, anyhow i have 5v pin 22 and i have 1.8 pin 20,21, and 16 looks like  i am missing 1.8v for  reset L on pin 18, checked rt806 which is also 0v, but when the board is first powered on 1.8v is there for about 3 sec, is this normal, also any suggestions what else to check

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on touch bar connectors with good board.
Because of liquid, M1 might suffer damage through its lines connected to touchbar.

What about first machine?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
checked diode mode reading, had short on the wire i ran, i replaced wire and retested, touch bar now powers lights up but no image just fine lines the entire touch bar.
first machine was set aside for now,  hoping to figure out the liquid damaged board and then come back the the other   I wasn't sure how to check arm sensors, there is no short on any of the pads, I ended up trying logic board with known good top case, then lost touch-bar completely figured best to set it aside for now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Test second board with known good touchbar.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: same outcome with new top case, , lights up but distorted colors/lines, if i leave jt700(liquid damaged, replaced connector) disconnected but leave jt710 connected touch bar stays the same, lit up, but no image, distorted lines perhaps my issue is with JT710

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
That should be; JT700 is dedicated for touch functions only.

Check LT710/11 continuity.
Also compare diode mode readings on JT710 lines with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Looks like jt710 has couple shorted pins, it’s clean but tested short, remive connector and pads were burned, intact but corroded and burned, was able to clean up pads. But don’t have a connector to put back on, any ideas where to buy, jt710 I have jt700 connectors but this one is unique

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
On the first board all diode readings are good on both connectors, but touchbar is dead, likely  it’s going to be a bad resistor or cap somewhere, the circuit, or SDA issue, will
Look for missing. Components,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Look for it on previous T2 boards...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I pulled one from scrap <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board, will resume woring on it tomorow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: ok, i pulled connector from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board, it was a match, but i knocked off component on back side while reinstalling new connector, part that came off is ut710,  is there another board i can pull this part from, i have tons on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>,and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board in scrap pile, i check pdf but not seeing it, hoping it has different part number for other boards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I'm afraid you can only find it in M1/2 boards.
However, with enough patience, you may use <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> for example.
You will need to place it upside down and solder with tiny wires...
